title: ‚òÖ The iPhones 15 Pro (and iPhones 15)
content:
Blah blah blah, something something something about how most people don‚Äôt upgrade their phones every year, so we ought not review new ones based on year-over-year comparisons. But, I get a new iPhone every year. A lot of you probably do too. So let‚Äôs just lean into a direct comparison between the iPhones 15 Pro and last year‚Äôs 14 Pro. After just under a week testing them, with the iPhone 15 Pro Max as my primary, I‚Äôve got four reasons to consider upgrading.

Titanium

I‚Äôm putting this first, even above the camera. Camera improvements are objective. The differences between titanium and the previous material for top-tier iPhones, polished stainless steel, are in many ways subjective. But the reduction in weight and better feel in hand are just so dramatic. Everyone uses their phone in different ways. There are some people out there who never take photographs or shoot video with their phones. But everyone carries and holds their iPhone. Making it a nicer object in hand is a huge win for a handheld tool.

We shy away from admitting it, at least of late, but gadget lust is real. People are drawn to exquisite objects and premium materials. New cars, new cameras, new watches (or newly-purchased old watches). Phones have been playing this game since long before Apple entered the industry. If you‚Äôre old enough, you remember the first time you saw a Motorola Razr. The way they snapped shut. The cool buttons. I remember thinking, Damn that‚Äôs cool. And before that era, this was cool.

I don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs any reason Apple used stainless steel for six generations‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâ2017‚Äôs iPhone X through last year‚Äôs 14 Pros‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâother than the fact that it looked cool, and looked premium. As I wrote last year, reviewing the iPhones 14 Pro, ‚ÄúIt certainly looks nice that it‚Äôs polished to a high gloss, but steel is just so damn heavy.‚Äù

Our long national nightmare of too-heavy iPhones is over.

Titanium is an upgrade in every way. First, it makes for dramatically lighter devices. I‚Äôve been testing all four new iPhone models, Pro and non-pro alike, and while the Pro models are a few grams heavier than the corresponding non-pro models using aluminum frames, the weight difference in hand is negligible. To compare cameras side-by-side, I‚Äôve been walking around with three phones‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâthe new iPhone 15 Pro Max and regular 15 Pro, and my year-old 14 Pro‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand I had to put cases made from distinct materials on the phones to tell them apart in my pocket, because the new 15 Pro Max feels about the weight of last year‚Äôs regular-size 14 Pro. It‚Äôs not the same weight, but it‚Äôs surprisingly close: 221g vs. 206g. The new regular-size 15 Pro weighs just 187g, compared to the aluminum iPhone 15 at 171g. But those numeric weight values don‚Äôt do justice to the feel. These new titanium iPhones Pro just feel strikingly lighter and better-balanced than the stainless steel iPhone Pro models they replace.

I also strongly prefer the way these new titanium frames both look and feel to the touch. My review unit 15 Pro Max is in natural titanium, and the 15 Pro is blue. Both are quite handsome. (And the blue titanium is a close match to the Midnight MacBook Airs.) Polished stainless steel is nice, of course, but it never jibed with my conception of the iPhone as a tool, like a traditional camera. You don‚Äôt see high-end cameras made from stainless steel‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâtoo heavy, too polished. The finish on the titanium frames of the iPhones 15 Pro is just terrific. It‚Äôs elegant, not industrial, but it conveys a certain let‚Äôs get to work seriousness. For pure hand feel alone, I‚Äôve preferred the non-pro iPhones in the 11‚Äì14 models. Now, I clearly prefer the feel of the 15 Pro models. It‚Äôs the best feel of an iPhone in hand since the lovely iPhone 5 and 5S, way back when iPhones were little slivers of a thing a decade ago. Looks-wise, the textured titanium is somewhat reminiscent of the brushed stainless steel of the iPhones 4 and 4S.

The buttons‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâside, volume, and Action‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâall have great clickiness and no wiggle. The button edges are crisp but not sharp.

Even if you, like many people, put your iPhone in a case the day you buy it and never see or feel the titanium again until the day you take it out of the case to trade it in for a new one, you win, because your iPhone 15 Pro will be so much lighter and better balanced. The titanium look and feel is a subjective win for those of us who go caseless most or even just much of the time. But it‚Äôs an undeniable win in weight reduction even for the always-cased.

Apple first used titanium in a product back with the 2001 PowerBook G4, the laptop that defined the basic roundrectilinear shape and metallic finish of Apple‚Äôs laptops to this day. That machine still looks remarkably modern for a 22-year-old computer, but it didn‚Äôt take long for Apple to abandon titanium for aluminum. Apple‚Äôs material science chops weren‚Äôt ready for titanium then‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâthose PowerBooks were painted, and the paint flaked over time. I‚Äôd argue they aged well, developing a patina, as watch collectors say, but they aged, and aged quickly.

Apple is fundamentally a computer company, but materials engineering is an essential arm of the company. How many years did we listen to Jony Ive-narrated introductory videos talking about aluminium and unibody construction? We take unibody laptop frames for granted now‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâthey‚Äôre just the way almost all high-quality laptops are made across the entire industry‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâbut it was a revolutionary technique at the time of introduction.

Apple is proud enough of its use of titanium in the iPhones 15 Pro that an entire segment of the keynote last week was presented by Isabel Yang, a materials science engineer. It‚Äôs a significant breakthrough, especially at the scale with which Apple needs to produce all iPhone models, particularly the Pro ones. I‚Äôve long suspected that the Edition models of Apple Watch have been a testing ground for materials they might someday use in high-production-quantity devices. Ceramic made for arguably the most beautiful watches Apple has ever made, but seemingly didn‚Äôt go anywhere‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâit was never even rumored as a potential material for the iPhone. The titanium Edition watches from Series 5‚Äì7, however, strike me as the devices that paved the way for last year‚Äôs Apple Watch Ultra and, now, the kings of the Apple lineup, the iPhones Pro.

It‚Äôs a rousing success that makes for the best feel in hand, by far, of the modern (post-X) iPhone era, and is unmatched by any competing phone maker. Top-tier Android phones are made from aluminum, Apple‚Äôs mid-tier material. Titanium is better functionally‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâit‚Äôs stronger‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand just as importantly, it‚Äôs just fucking cool.

Cameras

There are three major new camera features in the iPhone 15 models this year.1 First is a significant upgrade to the main camera (the one that covers the ranges 1√ó-2√ó optically). Second, Portrait mode has seen its biggest year-over-year improvement since the feature debuted. Third, and exclusive to the 15 Pro Max, is a new 5√ó telephoto camera, with a 120mm equivalent field of view. (The regular 15 Pro‚Äôs telephoto remains at 3√ó/77mm; the non-pro iPhones 15 have no telephoto lens.)

Main camera first. Last year Apple introduced a new 48 megapixel sensor for the 14 Pro main camera. It still produced 12MP images by default, clustering the 48MP sensor into a matrix of ‚Äúquad pixels‚Äù. Each 2√ó2 square of 4 native pixels on the sensor was used to create 1 pixel of the image. This technique traded detail for extra light sensitivity. You could opt to shoot ProRAW to get 48MP images with the iPhone 14 Pros, but that really is a professional feature. I consider myself a semi-serious prosumer photographer, but when it comes to shooting formats, I shoot very simply‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâusing the built-in Camera app, and the default format (HEIF). I care a lot about my photos, but I really do just point and shoot.

Last year the iPhone 14 Pro offered four ‚Äúlenses‚Äù from the three back cameras: 0.5√ó, 1√ó, 2√ó, and 3√ó. 0.5√ó was the ultra wide hardware camera. 3√ó was the telephoto. Both the 1√ó and 2√ó ‚Äúlenses‚Äù were from the same main camera, though. At 1√ó the camera system quad-binned the entire 48MP camera sensor; at 2√ó it used a 12 MP crop from the center of the camera sensor. The result is that for 2√ó photos, you still got a 12MP image, with far more detail and resolution than you‚Äôd get from shooting at 1√ó and then cropping to the center of the image in post.

This year with the iPhones 15 Pro, the ultra wide and telephoto situations are similar, except that on the Pro Max the telephoto is 5√ó instead of 3√ó. But the ‚ÄúPhotonic Engine‚Äù image processing pipeline for the main camera on both 15 Pro models is more advanced this year. Here‚Äôs how Apple describes it:

The Photonic Engine uses a new 48MP frame in our image pipeline, enabling iPhone to combine the best of low light‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâ12MP images with large quad pixels‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwith the best of detail‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâa 48MP image with individual pixels. This approach is an industry first, and it enables a new default resolution for the Main camera‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâa 24MP image with more detail, great low-light performance, and all the features users expect from an iPhone camera‚Äâ‚Äî‚ÄâDeep Fusion, Smart HDR, Live Photos, and zero shutter lag.

Take photos at 1√ó and compare to 12MP photos of other phones‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâ you see more details when you zoom in, especially when looking at hair, skin, or the texture of clothing.

Effectively, this is a next-generation step into computational photography. With quad pixels, you can easily see how the iPhone 14 Pro generated 12MP images from a 48MP sensor. It‚Äôs grade school division: 48 √∑ 4 = 12. But there is no 24MP sensor in the 15 Pro main camera. The Photonic Engine takes several images from the sensor for each photo, including a 48MP one for detail, and a 12MP quad-pixel one for low-light and noise reduction, then computationally fuses them together to produce a single 24MP image. Apple is having its cake and eating it too, merging the benefits of a sensor with many small pixels with the benefits of a sensor with fewer large pixels. You don‚Äôt need to know that this is happening, you just get more detail in your photos from the main camera.

I mentioned above that both the 1√ó and 2√ó ‚Äúlenses‚Äù on the iPhone 14 Pro use the same physical main camera. With the iPhones 15 Pro, Apple has added additional virtual lenses:

  • 1.0√ó ‚âà 24mm
  • 1.2√ó ‚âà 28mm
  • 1.5√ó ‚âà 35mm
  • 2.0√ó ‚âà 48mm

When shooting HEIC or JPEG (i.e. when you‚Äôre not shooting ProRAW), all focal ranges from 1.0 to 1.9 produce 24MP images. It‚Äôs effectively using computational photography to do optical zoom in this range from a the fixed-length main camera. In a certain sense it‚Äôs cropping, but it‚Äôs far removed from any simplistic cropping. There‚Äôs nothing magic about these particular stops between 1√ó and 2√ó other than the fact that 28 and 35mm equivalents have long been very popular focal lengths in traditional photography. You can ‚Äúzoom‚Äù to any focal length between 1‚Äì1.9√ó and you‚Äôll still get a 24MP image: 1.4√ó, 1.7√ó, 1.9√ó, whatever. 1.2√ó and 1.5√ó get special treatment in the Camera app simply because 28 and 35mm equivalents are so popular, and I believe Apple‚Äôs image processing pipeline is optimized for these lengths. [Update: I originally wrote that you get 24MP images from 1.0‚Äì2.0√ó, but that was slightly mistaken‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâonce you go from 1.9√ó to 2.0√ó, resolution drops to 12MP, presumably because at 2.0√ó the iPhone is using a precise center crop of the 48MP sensor.]

By default, when you repeatedly tap the 1√ó focal length button in the Camera app viewfinder, it cycles between 1.0/1.2/1.5√ó, and momentarily shows you the traditional equivalent after switching (24/28/35mm, respectively). You can adjust these options in the Camera section of the Settings app, including changing the default from 1√ó to 1.2√ó or 1.5√ó. For example, to simplify your options, you might consider turning off the preset for 1.2√ó/28mm, so that the 1√ó button in the viewfinder just toggles between 1.0 and 1.5√ó. I‚Äôm not sure what I want to do yet, personally, but I‚Äôm leaning toward keeping all three available, but changing my default to 1.5√ó/35mm, which I consider generally more natural looking for scenes and more flattering to human subjects.

You could always get the equivalent of these focal lengths by ‚Äúzooming‚Äù to 1.2√ó or 1.5√ó in the Camera app, but now you keep more native resolution from the image sensor.

It‚Äôs also worth noting that this improvement to the Photonic Engine comes to the non-pro iPhones 15 too, on their main camera, which also now sports a 48MP sensor. However, the non-pro iPhone 15 models don‚Äôt get the feature that treats 1.2√ó/28mm and 1.5√ó/35mm as discrete ‚Äúlenses‚Äù. And the hardware story is not as simple as ‚ÄúThis year‚Äôs non-pro iPhone 15 gets the 1√ó camera system from last year‚Äôs iPhone 14 Pro‚Äù. The 1√ó lens on the iPhone 15 and 15 Plus is a 26mm equivalent focal distance; the 1√ó lens on the iPhone 14 Pro (and this year‚Äôs 15 Pro models) is a 24mm equivalent. In my brief testing, the 1√ó hardware lens on the iPhone 15 models is noticeably inferior (or, if you prefer, less pro) to that on the Pro models, including last year‚Äôs iPhone 14 Pro. Shooting side-by-side in the same lighting, images from the iPhone 15 look flatter and lack vibrancy and contrast compared to those from the iPhone 15 (or 14) Pro. The camera system on the non-pro iPhones 15 seems fine, but if you care about photography, you want to get an iPhone Pro. It‚Äôs not just that the iPhones Pro have a telephoto lens and the non-pro ones don‚Äôt; the images from the main camera are noticeably better on iPhones Pro.

Another significant improvement this year is a much-improved Portrait mode. Apple claims improvements that boost detail and dynamic range, but the main improvement is that you no longer need to manually select Portrait mode before capturing. You can simply capture images using the regular still photo mode, and if a person, dog, or cat is detected, Portrait mode will be available via an ‚Äú∆í‚Äù button in the viewfinder, and you can toggle it off and on while shooting, and make adjustments to the background blur and focal distance in post. You get the same on-the-fly Portrait mode with the front-facing camera, too, on all iPhone 15 models.

I expect this to make a significant practical difference in my photography. In many situations, shooting candid pictures of friends and family, I just take out my iPhone, open the Camera app, frame the image, and start shooting‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâquickly and discreetly. When the moment feels fleeting, I don‚Äôt feel like I have time to futz with a manual switch to Portrait mode. A quick check of my Photos library shows that out of about 2,800 photos I shot with the iPhone 14 Pro in the last year, 233 were in Portrait mode. Those are some of my favorite photos of the last year, but I expect to wind up with way more Portrait mode photos this year, thanks to the dynamic on-the-fly application of Portrait mode. It‚Äôs a can‚Äôt-lose feature, because if you‚Äôre ever unhappy with the way a picture looks in Portrait mode, you can simply turn it off in post, and you‚Äôll wind up with the same image you would have had even if this automatic Portrait mode feature didn‚Äôt exist.

Lastly, now seems like a good place to reiterate that these new features all work with zero shutter lag. To date this has been a hard and fast rule for Apple‚Äôs Camera team‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâeverything happens instantaneously, and can be previewed live in the viewfinder before you capture. It‚Äôs intriguing to ponder what features Apple could enable if they allowed iPhones to ‚Äúdevelop‚Äù photos for a few seconds after capture, but I think I understand why they don‚Äôt. Once you allow some features to take post-capture processing time, it‚Äôs a slippery slope to an overall camera experience that feels slow and laggy. The iPhone camera has always felt fast and snappy, and the iPhone 15 lineup is no exception.

That brings us to the elephant in the room: the 5√ó lens exclusive to the iPhone 15 Pro Max. If you prefer a larger iPhone, well, you‚Äôre in luck, because you get that lens with the iPhone size you prefer. But if, like me, you prefer the regular-size iPhones, but, all things considered, would prefer the longest available telephoto lens, you have a decision to make.

Qualitatively the new 5√ó lens seems about as good as the recent 3√ó telephoto iPhone Pro lenses. Which is to say it‚Äôs fine, for a telephoto lens on a tiny (relative to ‚Äúreal‚Äù cameras) phone, but it‚Äôs nowhere near as good as the main camera. The 3D sensor-shift module seems to work like a charm to keep things stable‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâa real challenge at focal lengths like this. If you find yourself frequently wishing for more than 3√ó optical zoom with your current iPhone camera, you‚Äôre probably going to like this 5√ó lens a lot.

Me, though, I just don‚Äôt shoot many telephoto lens pictures or videos. Again, looking at my personal Photos library (and using Smart Albums to sort images by camera and lens), out of roughly 2,800 photos I‚Äôve taken with my iPhone 14 Pro, only 170 used the 3√ó telephoto lens. As a point of reference, 417 were shot with the ultra wide 0.5√ó lens, which includes all macro shots. Tallying up my lens usage for the last year reiterates my gut feeling: my ideal hypothetical iPhone might be an iPhone 15 Pro Mini, even if that meant having only two camera lenses instead of three, if those two cameras were the same 0.5√ó ultra wide and 1√ó main cameras as the actual iPhone 15 Pro models.

The biggest potential problem I might have with that hypothetical iPhone 15 Pro Mini of my dreams would be battery life, not the missing telephoto lens. I do occasionally use the telephoto lens I have, and I‚Äôm sure I will again this year, but not enough to justify an overall larger phone. Your mileage, of course, may vary. Some people love shooting with long lenses. Me, though, even when shooting with standalone cameras that use interchangeable lenses, I‚Äôve only ever bought prime lenses in the 28mm to 50mm range. I zoom with my feet.

One hitch with the iPhone Pro Max having a 5√ó telephoto lens is that if you really want a 3-4√ó focal length for framing, it needs to be digitally zoomed from the main camera. In my testing this doesn‚Äôt seem to make much difference, but more talented photographers might disagree. I tend to think that when I do want a long lens with extra reach, I might as well go really long.

In past years when the Plus-sized iPhones have had exclusive camera lenses, those lenses made their way down to the regular-size iPhones in the next model year. So I suspect Apple‚Äôs plan is for next year‚Äôs iPhone 16 Pro and Pro Max to both have 5√ó telephoto cameras based on this tetraprism design. I hope so, but if that doesn‚Äôt happen and 5√ó remains exclusive to the Max, so be it. The main camera is where the action is for me‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand that main camera has seen another terrific year-over-year upgrade with the 15 Pro models.

Action Button

It‚Äôs a little thing, literally, but I dig the new Action button.

A decade ago I was bewildered by the fact that of all the things Android phone makers had shamelessly copied from the iPhone, the mute switch wasn‚Äôt one of them. But then the iPad dropped its physical mute switch, and I could see the trade-off inherent to a physical switch: software control. With a physical mute switch, silent mode can‚Äôt be controlled by software, because software can‚Äôt flip the physical switch. (Carmakers, to name one common example, face this same dilemma with dashboard knobs and switches.) If a hardware button, knob, or switch has state, then that statefulness can‚Äôt be controlled by software unless the software can push, twist, or flip the physical controls.

If you just want a mute toggle, the new Action button is, I think, as good if not better than the old mute switch. No matter what action you assign to the button, it activates with a long-press, but that long-press delay is pretty short‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâit‚Äôs just long enough to avoid accidental activations, and is short enough that it never feels slow. When assigned to toggling silent mode, you get a quick series of haptic taps when it goes into silent mode, and one haptic tap when it goes out of silent mode. It‚Äôs easy to tell the haptics apart, if you‚Äôre using it without looking at it (like, say, if your iPhone is in your pocket or purse).

Because I‚Äôve been spending a lot of time testing the new cameras, I‚Äôve spent most of the last week with the Action button assigned to the Camera app. For many years now Apple has offered a shortcut to jump into the Camera app from the lock screen. There‚Äôs a button you can long-press in the lower-right corner of the lock screen, but the quickest way is to swipe right-to-left anywhere on the lock screen. I went into this thinking I might leave my Action button set to toggle silent mode, on the grounds that we already have these shortcuts for jumping into the Camera app, but one thing that‚Äôs become clear to me these past few days is that assigning the Action button to Camera is super useful when you want to jump to the Camera app while your iPhone is unlocked because you‚Äôre already using it. It‚Äôs cool and useful to have a button that always jumps you right into Camera no matter what state your iPhone is in.

So at the moment, I‚Äôm a bit torn between assigning my Action button to act as a mute switch or as a Camera launcher. Which brings me to another intriguing option: Shortcuts.

I created a simple workflow in Shortcuts that shows a menu with three options: Photo, Video, and Mute/Unmute. The Photo and Video options jump you to the corresponding shooting mode in the Camera app, and the Mute/Unmute option reverses the current setting for Silent mode. Shortcuts has built-in actions to enable and disable Silent mode on the device, but doesn‚Äôt have a built-in way to get the current Silent mode state. For that, my shortcut uses an action from the excellent free (and aptly-named) Actions utility by Sindre Sorhus. When Silent mode is engaged, the command is ‚Äúüîä Unmute‚Äù; when Silent mode is off, the command is ‚Äúüîá Mute‚Äù. (Now that there isn‚Äôt a physical switch to inspect, when Silent mode is engaged, the iPhones 15 Pro show a bell-with-line-through-it icon in the status bar, in the top left corner next to the time or carrier name. But it felt clever to make the menu item in my shortcut dynamically reflect the current state.) Here‚Äôs the shortcut, if you‚Äôre interested, and here‚Äôs a screenshot showing it in, err, action.

Is a menu like this a good use of the Action button? I‚Äôm not sure yet, but it sure is fun. The iPhones 15 Pro now have a dedicated hardware button that anyone can program using Shortcuts. I love it. One DF reader emailed me last week wondering if you can assign the Action button to act like an old-school Home button. You can, with Shortcuts. I can‚Äôt wait to see what others come up with.

[Update: I made a better version of this shortcut. Instead of showing a menu you need to choose from, it opens the Camera app unless the phone is face down or upside down, in which cases it toggles the state of Silent mode. I‚Äôve been using it this way for two days now and love it.]

USB-C

The overwhelming consensus seems to be that Apple only switched from Lightning to USB-C with the iPhones 15 due to the regulatory mandate from the EU. And, conversely, that Apple stayed with Lightning this long‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand if not for the EU regulation would stay with it for years to come‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâbecause they‚Äôre rolling in revenue from MFi licensing fees.

To the first part of that‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâthat Apple only switched because the EU forced their hand‚Äâ‚Äî‚ÄâI say Well, maybe. It‚Äôs obviously a factor. The EU is too big a market for Apple to walk away from. But the USB-C mandate doesn‚Äôt kick in until next year, and existing devices from 2023 and earlier will still be allowed when the regulation does kick in. So the iPhones 15 could have had Lightning ports and remained available in the EU for years to come. It‚Äôs next year when Apple would have to switch.

And if Apple really wanted to stick with Lightning, they could, in theory, make USB-C iPhones only for the EU market, and limit them all to the same USB 2 transfer speeds as Lightning. That would make for a supply chain hassle, to be sure, but it seems like less of a hassle than making iPhones with two SIM card trays just for the Hong Kong and Chinese markets.

As for the second part of the consensus thinking on why Apple has stuck with Lightning‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâthat it‚Äôs an MFi licensing money grab‚Äâ‚Äî‚ÄâI say Hogwash. Multiple sources have confirmed for me that MFi licensing revenue for Lightning devices and cables is negligible, just a rounding error by Apple‚Äôs standards. But consider the arrogance of thinking that Apple would spitefully hold the iPhone back just for a bit of licensing revenue. That Apple would knowingly make the iPhone worse for no benefit other than their own financial bottom line. That‚Äôs bonkers. I think the opposite is true: Apple pulls no punches when it comes to making the iPhone as good as it can possibly be for the most customers, even to the detriment of Apple‚Äôs other devices. For one thing, it would make more sense for bleeding edge Apple silicon to be designed first for the Mac, and to trickle down to the iPhone in subsequent years. But instead, Apple silicon is designed for and ships first for the iPhone, and then flows up to the Mac and iPad. The iPhone gets Apple‚Äôs best silicon (now on a 3nm process, the first in the world for any consumer product), best displays, and best materials (now titanium). It is the best device Apple can possibly make given the constraints of reasonable pricing and the inordinate scale at which it needs to produce them. No effort is spared‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâyear after year after year. And nothing, not even a global year-plus-long pandemic, could knock it off its annual schedule. Apple loves all its products, but it loves the iPhone most.

And but we‚Äôre supposed to believe that Apple deliberately made the iPhone‚Äôs charging and data port worse, for years, for a fistful or two of dollars? My god, the sheer arrogance it takes to believe that Apple takes for granted an iota of the iPhone‚Äôs success and enduring popularity.

The simple fact is that Apple kept all iPhones on Lightning while it thought staying on Lightning was the best choice for the most customers. I know that there have been engineers inside Apple‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâengineers who helped invent both Lightning and USB-C‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwho‚Äôve been advocating for the iPhone to switch from Lightning ever since USB-C debuted in MacBooks in 2015. Maybe Apple should have switched sooner. But there were good reasons not to, mostly surrounding the trust involved in building an ecosystem. When they switched from the 30-pin connector to Lightning, Phil Schiller said it would be the connector for ‚Äúthe next decade‚Äù. That was the iPhone 5 in 2012.

In actual use, I have to say it is a little weird having USB-C on the iPhone. I got curious and connected an iPhone 15 Pro to my iPad Pro to see what would happen. The first time, the iPhone started charging the iPad. That wasn‚Äôt what I expected, and from what I gather, isn‚Äôt supposed to happen. I unplugged the cable and tried again, and the same thing happened: the iPhone charged the iPad. I unplugged the cable and swapped one side of the cable for the other, and this time the iPad started charging the iPhone, as though the cable had a direction for charging. Craziness. I tried again and the iPad (a 2018 11-inch iPad Pro running iPadOS 17) crashed. I expect Apple will straighten this out, but I‚Äôm surprised it‚Äôs buggy at the moment.

Overall, though, it just isn‚Äôt that big a deal. It‚Äôs nice to know that 10 Gbps USB 3 transfer speeds are available for the iPhones 15 Pro‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâ20 times faster than the USB 2 limit of 480 Mbps (which remains the cap on the non-pro iPhone 15 models). But it‚Äôs irritating, as with all things related to ‚ÄúUSB-C‚Äù cables, that you‚Äôll need special (and more expensive) cables to achieve those transfer speeds, and there‚Äôs no way to identify which cables support which transfer speeds just by looking at them, unless they have the Thunderbolt logo on the connector‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâbut expensive, thick Thunderbolt cables are overkill for USB 3 data transfer. The cables that ship with all iPhone 15 models are nice, white2 braided cables, but are not high-speed USB 3 cables. (These cables from Monoprice are good options.)

The reason Apple opposed (and continues to oppose, even as their product line falls into compliance) the EU‚Äôs USB-C port mandate isn‚Äôt because they wanted to stick with Lightning forever. Why did they start migrating the iPad lineup from Lightning to USB-C back in 2018 if they were all-in on Lightning forever?
